meaning_mnemonic: You put a grain in your mouth and let it take a ride. This kanji has the same radicals as 和, but this time the grain is in your mouth, which is why there's little pieces of grain sticking out of the 口 part ;)
meaning_hint: Just imagine you're a car or a train and the grain is a person. It's going for a nice ride in your mouth!
reading_mnemonic: You decide the grain is probably lonely on this <kanji>ride</kanji> alone, so you add some <reading>no</reading>ri (の) seaweed, so it has a friend.
reading_hint: Now the nori is going for a ride too, woohoo!

meaning_mnemonic: What does your <radical>mama</radical> tell you to do in the <radical>street</radical>? Look before you cross! You gotta do it <kanji>beforehand</kanji>, or it could be too late.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself about to cross the street, and your mama saying in your ear: "always look beforehand"!
reading_mnemonic: As you look <kanji>beforehand</kanji>, you see a <reading>yo-</reading>yo (よ) lying in the street.
reading_hint: As you cross the road, you pick up the yo-yo and put it in your pocket. You're really glad you looked beforehand, because you now have a yo-yo!

meaning_mnemonic: You find a <radical>cross</radical> in the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>wolverine</radical>. What a strange <kanji>occurrence</kanji>. Why would someone do such a <kanji>thing</kanji>? This is a <kanji>matter</kanji> you want nothing to do with, so you'd better move along.
meaning_hint: Imagine that poor wolverine standing in front of you looking confused, with a cross in its mouth.
reading_mnemonic: This occurrence doesn't impress <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ), who appears and gently removes the cross from the wolverine's mouth.
reading_hint: Imagine Jesus gently taking the cross out of the wolverine's mouth. What a swell dude.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> is very <radical>anti</radical>-everything, making it all <kanji>temporary</kanji>. You get a new shirt, "I'm anti shirts!" she yells, and out it goes.
meaning_hint: She tires of things so quickly, you hardly have time to get used to them before they're gone.
reading_mnemonic: The leader's most <kanji>temporary</kanji> possession is her <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Or... cars, because they're all very temporary. She buys one, drives it around, and then suddenly she's anti red car. She needs a blue one!
reading_hint: Picture all of the temporary cars she's tried filling up an entire junkyard. They're all a little different, but in the end they were all just temporary fads.

meaning_mnemonic: A good <radical>leader</radical> can put the <radical>ground</radical>'s <radical>history</radical> to great <kanji>use</kanji>. You are a good leader. You have studied the ground and dirt of the earth your entire life. You know the history of the ground and you know how to use it to lead your people.
meaning_hint: Smell the ground. Waft the earthy smell of history into your leader-like nostrils. What does it smell like? It smells useful. And also like ground.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>use</kanji> the ground to raise <reading>shee</reading>p (し). When you were down there sniffing around you realized that your people will flourish best if you use this land for grazing and raising sheep.
reading_hint: When you use the ground for sheep like this, your people rejoice. You're the best leader ever! You always use everything to your advantage!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>tree</radical> <radical>leader</radical> is all about trying to <kanji>preserve</kanji> the trees. In fact, she <kanji>guarantee</kanji>s that she will preserve the trees if it's the last thing she does.
meaning_hint: Basically, a tree leader is someone who stands up for trees. Mostly she talks, but that can be a powerful skill to have.
reading_mnemonic: She chains herself to a tree to <kanji>preserve</kanji> them. But, unfortunately, the lumberjacks just take a giant back <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ) and tear this tree leader and the tree she's attached to in half.
reading_hint: What a terrible scene. Focus on the fact that they're using a horrible, modified back hoe. It's more like a weapon than a back hoe, and they show no mercy at all.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>elephant</radical>s is so great, they put up an <kanji>image</kanji> or <kanji>statue</kanji> of him everywhere. Every house, every street corner — his image looks down on all the other elephants at all times.
meaning_hint: For now, just imagine the leader of the elephants being told images and statues of him are being put up everywhere. Don't think about what the statue looks like, because that's next.
reading_mnemonic: When they unveil the <kanji>image</kanji>s and <kanji>statue</kanji>s of the leader elephant, everyone gasps. They look like him, but he's a <reading>zo</reading>mbie (ぞう). Gasp!
reading_hint: But this is exactly what the leader of the elephants asked for. You see, the leader of the elephants was a big fan of zombies. Imagine how excited he'd get to have this zombie version of himself appearing as images and statues, all across the land.

meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>eye</radical> and <radical>fins</radical> litter the <radical>ground</radical>. What happened? You killed a fish. You must hide the murder <kanji>tool</kanji> before someone finds out it was you.
meaning_hint: You feel the panic upon realizing what you've just done. This is murder in the first degree. You used a terrible tool to do it, and now you must hide it.
reading_mnemonic: There's <reading>goo</reading> (ぐ) all over your hands. Goopy goo. It's the guts of the fish you just killed and it's dripping off of the <kanji>tool</kanji> as well. Yuck.
reading_hint: That goo is really slimy. It's disgusting. You feel sick to your stomach. Please don't throw up, there's already enough junk on the ground with the eye and fins and all.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> grants a <radical>gladiator</radical> its <radical>power</radical> so he will <kanji>win</kanji>! <kanji>Victory</kanji> will be his!
meaning_hint: Watch as the moon's power fills the gladiator. He starts to glow, grows larger, and has some craters on his face now. Well.. okay.
reading_mnemonic: He <kanji>win</kanji>s over and over again, and soon the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) is even rooting for him. In fact, the Shougun claims him as his personal gladiator of choice.
reading_hint: The Shougun is only interested in people who win. But you probably could have guessed that already.

meaning_mnemonic:
You're sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> and someone <radical>cleat</radical>s you in the <radical>forehead</radical> as part of an <kanji>accept</kanji>ance ritual. It's for the most prestigious Spanish soccer club in the world. You got knocked off the stool, and the cleats really hurt your forehead, but you're just glad to have been accepted.

This kanji also means <kanji>receive</kanji>, which is quite similar to accept. It shouldn't be too hard to remember.
meaning_hint: You’re dealing with a lot of mixed emotions right now. You feel the pain from being cleated in the forehead and knocked clean off your stool, but you’re also glad to have finally been accepted into the soccer club. Suppress your pain. Accept this honor.
reading_mnemonic: After you've been <kanji>accept</kanji>ed, they give you a small <reading>ju</reading>ice (じゅ) box to help you recover from the trauma of getting kicked. And you <kanji>receive</kanji> it with grace.
reading_hint: Did you ever play soccer as a kid? Do you remember accepting a small juice box into your little kid hands during halftime? Apparently pros drink the same ones.

meaning_mnemonic: When everyone has <radical>grain</radical> in their <radical>mouth</radical>, you will have <kanji>peace</kanji>. That is the <kanji>Japanese style</kanji> of doing things.
meaning_hint: Imagine Japanese people with grain in their mouth. The whole country is at peace.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Peace</kanji> is the <kanji>Japanese style</kanji>. The <reading>wa</reading>lruses (わ) living off of Japan see this, and start to emulate.
reading_hint: The walruses also achieve peace by putting grain in every walrus' mouth, following the Japanese style.

meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>samurai</radical> with (just) his <radical>forehead</radical> and <radical>legs</radical>. Everything in between is missing. What happened to everything in between? He was low on money, so he had to <kanji>sell</kanji> it all, leaving him with only the top and the bottom.
meaning_hint: Imagine this terrifying samurai. You have legs… okay, that’s normal. But, then you have just a giant forehead on the top of everything else, walking around. It's pretty scary that someone would sell such important parts of their body.
reading_mnemonic: If you see a samurai trying to <kanji>sell</kanji> all their body parts here's what you should say, "<reading>Bye</reading> (ばい)!" and just get the heck out of there. Actually, if anyone tries to sell you a body part you should probably say bye over and over until you can get away from them.
reading_hint: Imagine saying, "Bye," loudly into the forehead of a samurai trying to sell you the rest of their face. If you say it loud enough it will distract them while you run away.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>roof</radical> is <radical>correct</radical> only if you <kanji>determine</kanji> that it is.
meaning_hint:
Imagine looking at a roof, and someone asks you, "Is this roof correct?"

"I determine it is."
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>determine</kanji>d it, but you still have to test this determination. You go to the top and roll a <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tot down the roof. Tater tots will only roll down a perfectly correct roof.
reading_hint: "Because of my tater tot roof test, I have once again determined it is correct."

meaning_mnemonic: Climb onto the <radical>roof</radical> in <radical>spring</radical> to see the <kanji>truth</kanji>. The world is waking back up from winter and revealing the <kanji>reality</kanji> of what it is all around you.
meaning_hint: Imagine sitting comfortably on your roof as the world around you changes to spring. Snow melts and reveals all of the truths that have been obscured and hidden in winter.
reading_mnemonic: At the moment, you're trying to learn the <kanji>truth</kanji> about the deer that is coming out of the snowy woods when you see not one, but two baby deer appear with it! <reading>Gee! Two</reading> (じつ) babies! You keep looking around and realize that all of the animals seem to have two babies that they had hidden in the snow.
reading_hint: Gee! Two babies! Reality sure is lovely.

meaning_mnemonic: Under your <radical>roof</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> there are more <radical>mouth</radical>s to feed because you let <kanji>guest</kanji>s stay with you when it's cold. Some of them aren't family, so they have to pay to stay under your roof and get food. Those are <kanji>customer</kanji>s.
meaning_hint: Picture all of the hungry guests and customers under your roof, eating your food and sleeping on your floor.
reading_mnemonic: One of your <kanji>guest</kanji>s is a regular named <reading>Kyaku</reading> (きゃく) the <kanji>customer</kanji>. Kyaku is always staying over at one place or another, so everyone knows their name.
reading_hint: Kyaku looks just like any other customer. Picture a stereotypical "customer" type person in your head.

meaning_mnemonic: Some of your <radical>private</radical> <radical>dirt</radical> is on the <radical>ground</radical>, so you stick a <radical>flag</radical> into it. Then on this private land you claimed, you build a <kanji>roof</kanji>. Under the roof you also build some <kanji>shop</kanji>s and <kanji>store</kanji>s.
meaning_hint: That's the natural next progression of claiming some land. Building a roof upon it and building some shops and stores inside. You'll see why in a moment.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>roof</kanji> covering the dirt is there so that the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や) can play baseball year round. The <kanji>store</kanji>s and <kanji>shop</kanji>s are there to sell hot dogs and Yankees memorabilia.
reading_hint: You have yourself a whole Yankees stadium, and all it took was a roof and some shops / stores! If you build it, they will come.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>yurt</radical>'s <radical>stool</radical> is always placed at certain <kanji>degree</kanji>s. The degrees change depending on specific <kanji>occurrence</kanji>s.
meaning_hint: Since a yurt is round, the stool has to be angled at certain degrees. It's part of yurt culture. Imagine someone adjusting the stool with a measurement tool to adjust it to an exact degree.
reading_mnemonic: Also angled at exact <kanji>degree</kanji>s is the <reading>do</reading>g (ど).
reading_hint: The dog changes its degrees at every occurrence of the stool changing. Picture the dog leaning at the exact degree the stool is at.

meaning_mnemonic: You need to get your <radical>fingers</radical> around a <radical>temple</radical> if you want to <kanji>hold</kanji> it. Is the temple too big? Hold smaller temples you can buy in the temple's souvenir shop.
meaning_hint: Imagine holding a tiny temple in your fingers. Hold it up to the light. Hold it on the train. Hold it while you sleep.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>hold</kanji> the temple you hear a voice. You look down through your fingers and see a tiny <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). He's smiling and gives you a thumbs up. Aww, thanks Jesus!
reading_hint: Jesus likes when you hold things like temples. He probably likes when you hold other things too, like ice cream, puppies, and homeless peoples' hands.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>stand</radical>ing <radical>tree</radical> that you're taking an <radical>axe</radical> to. You're going to cut down this tree to let a <kanji>new</kanji> tree grow.
meaning_hint: As you imagine yourself cutting down the standing tree, think about what new tree you'll plant in its place.
reading_mnemonic: You cut down the tree to make room for a <kanji>new</kanji> one, but it falls on your <reading>shin</reading> (しん).
reading_hint: Only your shin got hit, so focus all your imaginary pain down there. Try to pull out the splinters. Ouch!

meaning_mnemonic: Take the <radical>moon</radical> <radical>stamp</radical> on the <radical>stool</radical> in front of you and use it on all of your <kanji>clothes</kanji>. Now even if you sell or lose a piece of <kanji>clothing</kanji>, you'll be able to find it again by checking for your special moon stamp.
meaning_hint: Imagine placing each piece of clothing you own onto the stool and carefully stamping them with a symbol of the moon. This should stop people from stealing all of your clothes!
reading_mnemonic: A few days later you're with a friend when you recognize the <kanji>clothes</kanji> they're wearing. You grab it, rip it off, and scream, "<reading>F**k</reading> (ふく) you!" There is your moon stamp! These are your clothes!!
reading_hint: Your friend turns red and tries to pull the clothes back, "F**k you!" they yell. "No, f**k you, these are my clothes and I have proof this time!"

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>compare</radical> radical and the <kanji>compare</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Compare</kanji> the <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) today with the heat yesterday. Is it hotter today? It's up to you to compare.
reading_hint: Feel today's heat. Now compare it to yesterday. You might want to check your thermometer if you're not sure!

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> is going to last an <radical>eternity</radical> you better learn how to <kanji>swim</kanji> now. We'll be under water for the rest of time and if you can't swim you're not gonna make it.
meaning_hint: Picture most of the earth's population already swimming on the tsunami that will last the rest of eternity. Your floaties and life preservers would help you through this mess. You need to swim!
reading_mnemonic: <reading>Oy</reading> (およ)! Oy, stop daydreaming about <kanji>swim</kanji>ming and actually do it!
reading_hint: Picture yourself swimming in the tsunami with everyone else. You can't really talk to them, you're too busy swimming for your life, so you just shout "Oy!" to them and they shout it back.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>wing</radical>ed <radical>cow</radical> is flying in the air. What a strange <kanji>thing</kanji>! You’ve heard of flying pigs before, but cows? This is a new and strange thing indeed! Cows with wings! What a silly thing to imagine.
meaning_hint: Imagine if cows could fly. Wouldn’t you be jealous of them? I mean, if a cow can fly, any old thing should be able to, right?
reading_mnemonic: You want a <kanji>thing</kanji> to help you fly with the cow so you put on your flying <reading>boots</reading> (ぶつ). Your flying boots are a pretty strange thing in themselves, but they're the only way you can keep up.
reading_hint: Imagine a thing like flying boots. Do you believe such a thing could be real?

meaning_mnemonic: All the <radical>rice paddies</radical> are <radical>jammed in</radical>to the <kanji>world</kanji>.
meaning_hint: The world is basically just a bunch of rice paddies smooshed together, if you think about it.
reading_mnemonic: To get around this <kanji>world</kanji> of rice paddies, you need to use a <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい).
reading_hint: A rice paddy is mostly made up of water, just like our world, and you don't want to have wet feet. Use the power of your kayak to become a world traveler.

meaning_mnemonic: Once you remove the <radical>lantern</radical> from the <radical>tent</radical>, we will be ready for <kanji>departure</kanji>. We can’t leave the lantern inside of the tent; that’s a fire hazard. We’d best take it with us before the departure. Don’t you agree?
meaning_hint: Feel the heat from the lantern. It’s not quite as comforting as being inside a tent, but it’s better than nothing. The lantern will light your way on your departure.
reading_mnemonic: Oh! Don’t forget your <reading>hats</reading> (はつ) either. Wouldn’t want to start a <kanji>departure</kanji> without hats or a lantern. That’d be a short journey.
reading_hint: How cold and unprotected would your head be without a hat? Very. Taking hats along with departures is integral to their success. Imagine how unsafe you would feel with no hats. That’s no departure I want to set out on.

meaning_mnemonic: You need to look a <radical>tree</radical> in the <radical>eye</radical> to gain a <kanji>mutual</kanji> respect for each other. Stand up straight, look the tree directly in its eye(s). If it looks right back, you know things are mutual.
meaning_hint: It's the same with humans, you know? If you want to have a mutual relationship you need to be able to look each other in the eyes. If you're too embarrassed, or you look down on them, then that isn't mutual respect!
reading_mnemonic: If your respect for the tree is <kanji>mutual</kanji> with the respect the tree feels for you, you'll be able to see the tree's <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). Right now its soul looks pretty sad, like it's trying to say, "Why are your people cutting down all my friends? I thought we had a mutual understanding."
reading_hint: This is basically a FernGully moment, you know? You can feel the tree's pain like it's your pain. It's that kind of mutual sharing of souls you need.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical> of a <radical>small</radical> <radical>lion</radical> gazes upon the <kanji>prefecture</kanji> that will one day become his. He’s a small lion, but once he grows up, everything reflected in his eye will be his prefecture to rule over.
meaning_hint: Imagine the small lion casting his eye across his future prefecture. His small eye is twinkling, because he's proud that he'll one day be prefect, and this prefecture will be his.
reading_mnemonic: This small lion's <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is being protected by <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai because the lion is too small to protect all of this land himself. Ken the samurai is used to wandering far and wide, so one, eye-sized prefecture is nothing to him.
reading_hint: Picture Ken protecting the prefecture, punching hyenas in the face, and yelling, "This may just be a prefecture, not a country, but I'll give it my all for my lion prefect-to-be!"

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sheep</radical> that's <radical>big</radical> is a true <kanji>beauty</kanji>. Big is <kanji>beautiful</kanji>, and that's all the more true for sheep.
meaning_hint:
Imagine a great big beautiful sheep. See the sheep's beauty.

This sheep is so big and fluffy that you can't see its tail, which is why it looks bit different in this kanji.
reading_mnemonic: The big sheep's <kanji>beauty</kanji> has attracted a swarm of <reading>bee</reading>s (び). The sheep is so beautiful that the bees have mistaken it for a flower.
reading_hint: The bees are swarming around the sheep, marvelling at its beauty and trying to figure out how to get nectar from it.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Old</radical> <radical>flowers</radical> are <kanji>suffering</kanji> because they're old.
meaning_hint: Old things go through a lot of suffering because their bodies are breaking down. Flowers are no different from you and me.
reading_mnemonic: If an old flower (or person) is <kanji>suffering</kanji>, give them a <reading>coo</reading>kie (く).
reading_hint: No one can resist a good cookie. It will ease your suffering, or at least distract you for a little bit.

meaning_mnemonic: Sometimes <radical>life</radical> gives you a <radical>kick</radical>, and you have to <kanji>express</kanji> yourself to deal with it! How do you express yourself? On the <kanji>surface</kanji> (of your face)!
meaning_hint: Think of the last time life gave you a kick, and how you expressed that pain to make it go away, specifically on the surface that is your face.
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>express</kanji> yourself, so you call up a friend and say "<reading>Heyo</reading>!" (ひょう).
reading_hint: Imagine yourself saying it more like ひょう, though. ひょう man!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> who pilots a <radical>helicopter</radical> will have the insatiable <kanji>need</kanji> for something. She doesn't know what it is. But she needs it. And that's why she's flying around looking for it!
meaning_hint: Picture the woman in the helicopter needing something. She's looking around. Searching. But she doesn't know what it is!
reading_mnemonic: Finally she knows what she <kanji>need</kanji>s! It's <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう)! Delicious, creamy yogurt!
reading_hint: What does she need? Yogurt!

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>say</radical> something at a <radical>ceremony</radical> for <radical>construction</radical> workers you're going to have to <kanji>try</kanji> really hard. Construction is loud, so if you want to be heard you have to <kanji>attempt</kanji> to be louder than the drilling and smashing and digging and handing out of awards.
meaning_hint: Try to imagine trying this hard to be heard. The construction workers are all screaming at each other with ease. It's so hard for you to try and keep up with their volume!
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>try</kanji> to get their attention the only way you know how, by lifting a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) above your head. The sheep baas and suddenly everything is silent, all eyes are on you. Well, they're on the sheep.
reading_hint: Huh. You should have thought to try this sheep technique earlier.

meaning_mnemonic: You  <radical>say</radical> things around a  <radical>fire</radical>. In fact there are two  <radical>fire</radical>s, and you're <kanji>talk</kanji>ing with a group of people, all sitting around two nice campfires.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself next to the two campfires, having a heart-to-heart talk. What are you saying?
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>talk</kanji> in this intense, fiery way all the way until <reading>dawn</reading> (だん), but no longer! Once dawn comes the discussion needs to be concluded.
reading_hint: If you try to talk all night and past dawn, you'll burn out. Take the day, think, then tonight you can try to have an all-night talk again.

meaning_mnemonic: When you're in <radical>prison</radical>, whoever ends up with the <radical>shellfish</radical> will <kanji>lose</kanji>. It's the game all prisoners play. It's like keep away from the shellfish. And if you end up with the shellfish BZZZZTT that's it, you're the loser.
meaning_hint: Imagine that it's your first day in prison. You're walking around the yard, minding your own business, when suddenly a shellfish smacks you right in the head and falls into your open hands. "HAHA YOU LOSE!" someone shouts.
reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>lose</kanji>, you're a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). All you had to do was not hold the prison shellfish. It really shouldn't have been that hard to not lose, ya fool.
reading_hint: Now you have to try to make some other fool lose. Otherwise you'll be the loser fool forever.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>spicy</radical> radical and <kanji>spicy</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Hot!
reading_mnemonic: When you eat <kanji>spicy</kanji> food, it gives a <reading>から</reading>て chop to your mouth. That's where that spicy feeling comes from!
reading_hint: Imagine a bunch of little black belt spice molecules からて punching, kicking and chopping all the way through your mouth and into your throat and nasal passages. Oww, it's pure agony!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>scooter</radical> is <radical>anti</radical> scoot. It doesn't want to run. So you have to <kanji>return</kanji> it.
meaning_hint: Unfortunately, now you have to return to the store to return this scooter, but you have no scooter to get there with. Ugh.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>return</kanji> to the store and wait in line to return the scooter but the person working returns doesn't want you to return it. He stares you dead in the eyes, waves his hand, and turns you into a <reading>hen</reading> (へん)!
reading_hint: The employee leans down toward you in hen form and says, "Ooh, I'm sorry. We don't take returns from hens. You'll have to just return home."

vocabulary.meaning: To Show Someone What One Can Do

meaning_mnemonic: On its <radical>scooter</radical>, a <radical>horn</radical>ed creature from <radical>heaven</radical> will take things you want to <kanji>send</kanji> there.
meaning_hint: Picture the horned thing on its scooter, a big messenger bag over its shoulder with the kanji for heaven on it. "You got somethin' you want me to send?" it mutters.
reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>send</kanji> your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) to heaven. I mean, you don't want it to go to some of those other places you've heard of, so why not send your soul?
reading_hint: You put your soul into an envelope, stick a stamp on it, and hand it off to be sent to heaven. Bye bye! I hope this doesn't have any negative effects on your body!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>clown</radical> <radical>building</radical> is over in that <kanji>part</kanji> of town. We keep the clown part as separate as we can from the rest of the normal people. In fact, the entire clown education <kanji>department</kanji> and their clown <kanji>club</kanji>s have to stay in their part, they can't come in ours.
meaning_hint: Of course, we feel terrible about forcing the clowns into their own part of town. It's not that they're lesser than us, it's just that we don't like them.
reading_mnemonic: You see, that <kanji>part</kanji> of town is full of <reading>boo</reading>ze (ぶ). Clowns need a lot of booze to keep their charade going, so we just let them have it. But they aren't allowed in our part anymore, because they all stink of nasty clown booze.
reading_hint: Picture all of the clowns, trapped in their weird clown part of town, drinking booze and smashing each other over the heads with the bottles. You're glad you don't live in that part.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>heavy</radical> radical and the <kanji>heavy</kanji> kanji are the same.
meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
reading_mnemonic: In your hand is a very <kanji>heavy</kanji> <reading>jew</reading>el (じゅう). Real jewels are always heavier than they look.
reading_hint: Imagine holding a real jewel in your right hand and a fake jewel in your left. The one in your right hand is suuuuupeerrr heavy!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> and a <radical>squid</radical> are going to <kanji>test</kanji> you.
meaning_hint: Imagine the horse and squid in a big testing room, getting ready to test you. What are they testing you on? Weirdly, they're going to test you on all the kanji that use horse and squid radicals. You ready?
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>test</kanji> is being supervised by <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai.
reading_hint: To make sure you don't cheat on the horse and the squid test, Ken the samurai is watching you closely, pacing up and down. Every now and then, he waves his katana menacingly.
